transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legge and Bren Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Well, hello and welcome to this episode of the Reconstructed Faith podcast. My name is Colson Lechner, and this episode is a continuation of our interview with David Zoll. And now if you're not familiar with David Zoll, or you didn't tune into our first episode, I would encourage you to listen back to the first episode to get some more information. But just a little bit about David, he was born in New York City, but now lives in Charlottesville, Virginia, as he said, in central Virginia. And he's the founder of Mockingbird Ministries, which is an organization devoted to connecting the Christian faith with the realities of everyday life in fresh and down to earth ways. So you should definitely check them out online. In addition to being the executive director of Mockingbird, David has authored many books, included his latest work, Low Anthropology, The Unlikely Key to a Gracious View of Others and Yourself. We will talk a little bit about that and hear some of David's thoughts in this episode about low anthropology. David also serves on the staff of Christ Episcopal Church, and he and his wife Kate have three sons. So we hope you enjoy this episode. If you have any questions, hit us up. I remember when I got invited to come do just a quick devotional at the Mockingbird Conference here, and I saw you were speaking on the schedule right before me and that the name of your new book was Low Anthropology. I quite literally laughed out loud. I was like, of course it is. Of course, David sees this. And I can't wait to hear him talk about this. So could you do your best marketing campaign for your book? Because I feel like this is such a pattern that half of the problem is people are deconstructing their faith in God, unreasonably, irrationally, or even without good intuition. But then the worst is they then somehow are increasing their confidence and construction in themselves. One of our themes around here that I say from the pulpit all the time is like, have you met you? Have you met any humans? I mean, if you weren't you, would you want to be enslaved to you? And if the answer to that is no, then you being you doesn't improve you as a slave master. Like we are terrible slave masters. And the thought that you would, you would think like, Oh, I know I've got a much, much better choice, a safer choice to build my life on. And it's me. And I'm like, God, I just feel like maybe you haven't met you then. And so anyway, I want to hear where this came from and where this emphasis came from. Yeah. What led to it? Yeah. Cause like, I want to hear that. I want to hear that as well. Sure. Well, okay. The low anthropology is my, I think everyone has an anthropology by that. I mean that everyone has some kind of operating conception of human nature. Like we all have something we mean when we say the phrase, I'm only human. And that conception, and sometimes again, sometimes it's explicit and sometimes it's just sort of, you know, unconscious, that creates expectations in the way that for ourselves and for other people in our jobs, in our marriages, in our, you know, politics, et cetera, et cetera. And so my sense is that I was looking around and I'm always wanting to pay attention to what people are actually suffering from. And I was looking at two different issues that I feel are pretty acute today. And one of them is burnout. I was looking, you know, it was pre-COVID actually is when burnout became a kind of a term. And you might, today it's even burnout has become a burned out, how people talk about fatigue instead, exhaustion. And then you had like them reporting on like, you know, retirees were feeling burned out and high school kids were feeling burned out. And so I was wondering what's going on with burnout and the other big emotional albatross was be loneliness. And maybe you guys saw about this very past week that we're recording this, this US surgeon general declared loneliness, the big new public health as dangerous as smoking. Yes. 15 cigarettes a day. Yep. And I thought to myself, what's going on with these two things of loneliness and burnout? And I, and how does this relate to our anthropology? And so my sense is that burnout is usually the result of excessive demands and understanding of the human being is being capable of more than the human being is actually capable of. And this is, you know, there are profit driven reasons for this. There are other reasons for it. But we expect this too much of ourselves. And so we've lost any conception that we are limited, I would say creatures we created, we're not we're there's, again, there's a God and he's not you, you know, but we've lost that. And so as a result, we have ever increasing demands on us. One, one philosopher calls it the culture of acceleration so that everything's always increasing. And when I say the real person, that usually means the ugly part of you, the less perfect than perfect part of you, it's just how you know, you feel admired for your attributes and for your achievements, you feel loved by the people who see the stuff you leave off your resume and stick around. And so in both cases, I felt this was the fruit of a high anthropology, a inflated view of human beings, as human beings as being sort of very few limits, they're optimizable, maybe not perfectable, but optimizable, that's the word you always hear. And that can be in a counseling setting. It can be in, in a, those are, those are some great options. So yeah, we would, we would say the same thing. Just don't the, the, the, the answer of just stopping at the deconstruction level. Um, we've just not found that to be necessary and we can keep, we can keep working. Cough up the hairball. David's all that's, uh, up there. Well, that's right. We'll be coming back to that one. I'm sure many times. Yeah. Well, David, thank you so much. Yeah. For your thoughtful responses, man. Seriously. It's been so good. I'm excited to go read your book. I haven't had a chance to read it yet. I'm, my husband's read it and I'm so excited now. Oh, well, thanks, Bryn. Thank you, Colson. Thank you, Chris, for having me. I hope it's, I don't know. I mean, I honestly am an actual low anthropologist. I hope, I hope what I've said has been helpful. It's been amazing. It's been really great. It's been a lot of words. It's been a lot of words. Well, we really appreciate it. The people who are listening that we've found or the people that are sending their friends to this or their kids to this, this, this podcast, um, that's what the, sometimes the, the stories, the individual stories that as what we've wrestled through and others have wrestled through have been really compelling to them. And, and why that if you have a realistic perspective, why haven't you walked away? Well, that's, we, they need, they need to hear that. They need to hear some examples of, I'm not, I'm not pretending like there's no, you know, this is a, not a pay no attention to the man behind the curtain kind of faith. Um, and so if I'm, if I'm honest about the stuff that's going on behind the curtain, how can I stick with it? And what's the real story here? So I appreciate that David very much. And I, I do recommend your materials, your, the conferences you do, the, the teaching you do. I have been, I love that it makes me think differently than my intuition is time after time. Um, and I find my spirit, encouraged by that. So David, thank you. Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.

segments.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your
life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable,
substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legge and Bren Starnes.
This is Reconstructed Faith.
Well, hello and welcome to this episode of the Reconstructed Faith podcast. My name is
Colson Lechner, and this episode is a continuation of our interview with David Zoll. And now if
you're not familiar with David Zoll, or you didn't tune into our first episode, I would
encourage you to listen back to the first episode to get some more information. But just
a little bit about David, he was born in New York City, but now lives in Charlottesville,
Virginia, as he said, in central Virginia. And he's the founder of Mockingbird Ministries,
which is an organization devoted to connecting the Christian faith with the realities of
everyday life in fresh and down to earth ways. So you should definitely check them out online.
In addition to being the executive director of Mockingbird, David has authored many books,
included his latest work, Low Anthropology, The Unlikely Key to a Gracious View of Others
and Yourself. We will talk a little bit about that and hear some of David's thoughts in
this episode about low anthropology. David also serves on the staff of Christ Episcopal
Church, and he and his wife Kate have three sons. So we hope you enjoy this episode. If
you have any questions, hit us up.
I remember when I got invited to come do just a quick devotional at the Mockingbird
Conference here, and I saw you were speaking on the schedule right before me and that the
name of your new book was Low Anthropology. I quite literally laughed out loud. I was like,
of course it is. Of course, David sees this. And I can't wait to hear him talk about this. So
could you do your best marketing campaign for your book? Because I feel like this is such a
pattern that half of the problem is people are deconstructing their faith in God,
unreasonably, irrationally, or even without good intuition. But then the worst is they then
somehow are increasing their confidence and construction in themselves. One of our themes
around here that I say from the pulpit all the time is like, have you met you? Have you met
any humans? I mean, if you weren't you, would you want to be enslaved to you? And if the answer
to that is no, then you being you doesn't improve you as a slave master. Like we are terrible slave
masters. And the thought that you would, you would think like, Oh, I know I've got a much,
much better choice, a safer choice to build my life on. And it's me. And I'm like, God, I just
feel like maybe you haven't met you then. And so anyway, I want to hear where this came from and
where this emphasis came from. Yeah. What led to it? Yeah. Cause like, I want to hear that. I want
to hear that as well. Sure. Well, okay. The low anthropology is my, I think everyone has an
anthropology by that. I mean that everyone has some kind of operating conception of human nature.
Like we all have something we mean when we say the phrase, I'm only human. And that conception,
and sometimes again, sometimes it's explicit and sometimes it's just sort of, you know, unconscious,
that creates expectations in the way that for ourselves and for other people in our jobs,
in our marriages, in our, you know, politics, et cetera, et cetera. And so my sense is that I was
looking around and I'm always wanting to pay attention to what people are actually suffering
from. And I was looking at two different issues that I feel are pretty acute today. And one of them
is burnout. I was looking, you know, it was pre-COVID actually is when burnout became a kind of
a term. And you might, today it's even burnout has become a burned out, how people talk about fatigue
instead, exhaustion. And, you know, you had, you know, millennials were feeling this way,
you know, nurses and doctors were feeling burned out and parents of young children were feeling
burned out. And then you had like them reporting on like, you know, retirees were feeling burned
out and high school kids were feeling burned out. And so I was wondering what's going on with
burnout and the other big emotional albatross was be loneliness. And maybe you guys saw about this
very past week that we're recording this, this US surgeon general declared loneliness, the big new
public health as dangerous as smoking. Yes. 15 cigarettes a day. Yep. And I thought to myself,
what's going on with these two things of loneliness and burnout? And I, and how does this relate to our
anthropology? And so my sense is that burnout is usually the result of excessive demands and
understanding of the human being is being capable of more than the human being is actually capable
of. And this is, you know, there are profit driven reasons for this. There are other reasons for it.
But we expect this too much of ourselves. And so we've lost any conception that we are limited,
I would say creatures we created, we're not we're there's, again, there's a God and he's not you,
you know, but we've lost that. And so as a result, we have ever increasing demands on us. One, one
philosopher calls it the culture of acceleration so that everything's always increasing. And that is
producing burnout in every conceivable arena, emotionally, all this sort of paralysis and
fatigue. And the other thing is loneliness, we have a, we have an intolerance of kind of weakness.
And so this is in large part facilitated by social media, and that we're never allowed to really,
we're constantly dealing with a projection, a facade of who we are, who we think we should be
in order to get love. And of course, even when that facade gets approval and likes and all this
stuff and vibe goes viral, you actually feel more alone because you know, that's not you to any
for any kind of love to occur in human life, it has to involve the real person. And when I say the
real person, that usually means the ugly part of you, the less perfect than perfect part of you,
it's just how you know, you feel admired for your attributes and for your achievements,
you feel loved by the people who see the stuff you leave off your resume and stick around.
And so in both cases, I felt this was the fruit of a high anthropology, a inflated view of human
beings, as human beings as being sort of very few limits, they're optimizable, maybe not perfectable,
but optimizable, that's the word you always hear. And that, that we need to constantly be presenting
a that our actual selves are, there's a complete intolerance of those those things. And so low
anthropology is my attempt to say that, in fact, the opposite is true. In order to foster more unity,
compassion, and love and patience in the world, we need to begin from a lower anthropology. And that
for me is a biblical anthropology that's, which says that human beings are limited, we're created
by God, we're not God. And for finite for that reason, and that we are, I'd say doubled, we are
in all sorts of ways conflicted, or we're emotionally driven, we say one thing and do
another, we're, we're oftentimes a mystery to ourselves, we're not sort of, let me tell you
what to do, and you'll do it, that just has never worked. And any system that operates according
those lines is going to produce mass frustration, and, you know, rebellion. And then finally, that
we are compromised in some way, I would, as I would say, we are sinners, we are rebellious, we are,
right, we actively, it's not that we don't do what we want, we actively want the wrong thing.
Sometimes, right, exactly. And so I think that birth's a form of what, in terms of speaking,
what Chris is talking about, I'm trying to promote a healthy self skepticism. I don't,
I wouldn't call it people when they hear about sin, sin, you know, original sin, the, the world out
there hears self loathing. That's what, right, right, you're talking about shame. And I think
actually shame is really a product of feeling like you're the only one who's like this, and everyone
else somehow has these moral superpowers. And if the people really knew, you know, that what you
were like, well, then they really would hate you. And that's, that's, that's really shame. It's the
idea that we can be perfect, we just haven't pulled it off yet. And so low anthropology,
I think, is about love, and it's about ultimately a relationship with God, I wrote the book to try to
make an emotionally plausible case for faith in God. That's a lot.
That's great. I will tell you, you know, I work in the, in the therapeutic world talking about shame.
I think shame, especially when we talk about it from a cultural perspective, shame is that
cultural construct that's meant to make you feel like you're the outsider, you're the one who
doesn't belong, you're the one who doesn't fit in. So I totally agree. I like that concept that,
that shame is meant to make you feel like you're the only one with this problem. And
when I talk about intimacy, I often will talk about, you ever, David, you ever been on a cruise?
Yeah, I have actually. Yeah. Okay. So, so you go to these, go to these ports and you go to the
port, like at Cozumel or St. Thomas or something. And you, and when you go in, they drop you off at
this pier and at the pier is this city. It's this little cruise city. It's clean. It's neat. It's got
the best stores. It's got all this great stuff. And, and the vast majority of people on the cruise,
that's as far as they go. There's usually like the one at Cozumel actually has a wall built around
it. Like you have to find the exit. It's not easy to actually leave the little cruise city there.
And everything's overpriced, but it's all pristine. Like it's all perfect. And, and they spray it off
every day and everything. But what's, what's wild is you get, you get outside of that little cruise
city. And that's where, of course there's poverty and there's difficulty and there's challenges and
there's all the ugly side and the most beautiful and the most stunning and the most shocking things
on the Island are also, they're all outside of that, outside of that. And I tell you, I will tell
you most, most people, we want people to love us in that city because that's where we feel most
comfortable. Hey, that's where I'm at my best. And so I want you to, I think it's where I'm at my best.
And so like, that's where I want you to approve of me as inside those, those little walls. And,
and the idea of letting you pass those walls is, is scary. It can be scary because back there,
yeah, the best things are about me are probably back there, but I can't control which necessarily
is easily what you see and what you don't see back there. And you might reject me. Right.
And that's where love, love could occur, but also rejection. That's right. And so it's a true love,
not just you love what I'm presenting to you, but you, you love the real person who's there.
And, and so I think that's really tough for us and it requires a courage that I don't know how
people who don't have a mindset of a God who knows perfectly everything about the Island,
even better than I do and chooses me anyway. Like that's the, that's the root. Like you can
reject me because in the end I can survive that as hard as that may be. And as painful as that may be,
because there's someone who's even more right than you are who is choosing to accept me,
even though they understand me so well. And that, I don't know how to get the courage outside of that
to risk it. Yeah, it's hard. Well, and too, it's so interesting to think about the counter-cultural
aspect of this message, like you're saying, where to culture, having a high anthropology
would think on the, on the outset would be loving because you're viewing people as like,
Oh, we're capable of anything. Like it views people in a loving way, but in like viewing
people with a lower anthropology actually allows for truly loving others instead of just loving
like a perfected version of them. Or I don't know. That's interesting of like
seeing people for what we really are, like you're saying, allows for an actual unconditional love
and for us to experience that from the Lord and then show it to others. That's right. I don't know.
We think we'll bring people together by celebrating our shared virtues. But the truth is you actually
bring people together by identifying their shared weaknesses. And that's just 100% true,
I would say in almost all aspects. If I meet someone who's, you know, politics on Facebook
are just absolutely reprehensible to me. And that's all I see about them. And I cannot unite. In fact,
the more they talk about this thing that they think is good, the further along I feel from them. But
the second they put up the post that their loved one has died, I have an outpouring of love. And I
say, oh my gosh, I've lost someone too. And I may not know, I may not agree with this person,
but I feel closer to them as a result of the fact that we both have a shared experience of loss.
That same thing happens in addiction circles. You know, the same thing happens, I think,
theoretically and very practically in like a good small group at church. You know, this is the
truth. If you want to see an increase in unity, compassion, tolerance, humor, you have to
recalibrate your understanding of human nature down a few notches. And people hear, oh, that's
what about the Imago day? And you want to say, well, of course the Imago day. People are,
the world is full of awe and wonder. And what a wonderful thing to walk through it and be
surprised by how much God is at work through and, you know, around people rather than constantly
resentful for people for actually being just like you. And I really, you know, in terms of the way
this works out in deconstruction, by the way, is when you listen to stories of deconstruction,
a lot of times people are deconstructing a high anthropology view of religion where they thought
eyes was told that Christians never suffered, or I was told that Christians were no longer sinful.
I was told that I should be different at more different. And you know, in many ways,
I believe the Holy Spirit works and people experience profound, you know, victory in
certain areas. And yet we never get to the point where we need God any less. Right. And yet that
is what's communicated. And so a low anthropology says, in fact, no, you will always be a person
who needs God, never a person who is needed by God. And I mean, God loves you, and he wants to
use you in all sorts of ways. However, the bedrock of our shared humanity is our shared need.
And I think that that, but what I hear in stories of deconstruction is oftentimes like there's a
hierarchy, and there's a good Christian and a bad Christian. And there's, you know, you should, once
I was, I was told that once I became a Christian, I would no longer be like this. And then I, and I
have to adopt some false narrative of improvement that it, the more I adopted, the worse it gets.
And then all of a sudden, I'm living two distinct lives. And finally, the house of cards comes
crashing down because I can't do it. And low anthropology allows God to be God, I believe.
That's, that's why I wrote the book. I think it is descriptively true, but also
theologically alluring in a very powerful way. Yeah.
So, so you're saying that you even feel like low anthropology or high anthropology is a problem in
culture, but then we can twist it and it's still tempting in church culture and Christianity to
ascribe to a high anthropology, because it's, it's shiny, it's, you know, appealing. But it's not the
true gospel. And that's the catalyst for a lot of deconstruction. Is that like, am I hearing that?
That's your, yeah, I mean, that's what I believe. I think that's true. That, yes, the high
anthropology works its way out, works its way into religion. The way that it does it is it says,
you know, people usually become Christians through some sort of appeal or some sort of experience of
God where they feel they were loved as they really were. They were forgiven. They were, they heard some
revival, some sermon where they were saying, this is the gospel, that God knows you and actually
still loves you. And Jesus shed blood on your behalf, covers you in, you know, in righteousness.
And you have been given this gift of God's grace and eternal life. And that's extremely exciting and
good news to people who've really messed up in their life and want a second chance, a third chance,
a fourth chance, a fifth chance. And so of course you run to it. But then what happens is, and that's
a low anthropology, that's, that's Christianity. But then what happens is, well, now that you're
Christian, you're imbued with these sort of superpowers and you no longer, there are those people
out there that need God, but not you really. Or you need God less. And that's, the gospel is just
for them. And then it becomes this inner game of a tennis that, of ladder climbing. And people feel
like they're on a ladder at church rather than church is the place I think we go when we fall
off the ladder. But we're brilliant at constructing ladders. We're just really, really good at it. And
you know, we do it, by the way, at Whole Foods and it's all cycled the same way. And it, you know,
on Facebook or whatever. But yeah, I think that it's pernicious because a low anthropology allows
for God to do great work in people's lives that you want to tell those stories. But once the
stories become the point, rather than, you know, what is Jesus? Jesus says, like, I perform these
signs and wonders, but you don't believe like you want to put your faith in the signs and wonders
rather than in God. And we want to do the same thing. The second we start putting our faith in
the signs and wonders that we've seen in our own lives, what we find is that it all falls apart,
because these things were testimonies to God's faithfulness. They weren't objects of faith in
themselves. That's getting mighty theological, I guess. But I would say that yes, high anthropology
works its way into religion. If you've ever heard someone say, I just couldn't keep up anymore. I
just couldn't keep it up, keep going. They're dealing with some sort of high anthropology
form of religion. Yes. And that's, to me, it's very, very difficult to tell that sometimes from
humanism. It's a religion in which God kind of worships us. Like God becomes a humanist
sometimes in that high anthropology versus us realizing that the things that are good in us
are really gifts that He has given us. It's not because we've earned it or merited it. It's not
something somehow particularly special about us that makes us, like even the Imago Dei is a great
example. Like, it's not like I earned the image of God. It's not like I somehow merited that,
grunted that out, made that happen. It really does come down to that. It's a gift God gave me.
And so, yeah, it's true of me, but it's true of me because of Him. And that's freeing it. Because
that also means I'm not the one who's going to somehow lose it. Like I'm not the one who's going
to misplace it. Being created in the image of God is not something that I can wander off without
and forget or leave it behind. Or that me being in denial of it or someone else being in denial of it
doesn't make it not true. Because that would be terrifying. And I was in a version of Christianity
that had not quite that, it had that about a right relationship with God, that it was up to me to
maintain that. And it was kind of terrifying, to be honest. Like it was like a man.
Yeah. And the difficulty is a lot of this stuff becomes implicit rather than people would say,
well, of course God is the one doing, is the perfecter of your faith. Of course,
this is all God's doing. But once there becomes like a, it's almost like a dispositional,
an attitude that people start to say, well, yeah, but you should really be kind of getting a little
better here. And so that's why it's hard to parse exactly where this switch flips. And that doesn't
always flip. Sometimes it's just what the crazy, our own brokenness that we bring to the equation
that seems to make, is desperate to make a ladder out of anything, even the gospel. But I think that
that's why the job of the pastor is really to proclaim the gospel message over and over again
in such a way that it's honest and it takes into account the real pain of life, but doesn't hedge
on the sovereignty of God or the grace that is on offer, even for you, the Christian,
even for you, the church goer, even for you, the deconstructor.
That's really good. That's really good. All right. Anything else come to mind?
What comes to mind is these are great things and you were kind of revisiting what you were talking
about earlier with youth ministry. How does this play out, David, like within your, I'm just
thinking of your relationship with your sons and how you're wanting to create, I'm sure,
a culture within your home and then also within your church more broadly
that is allowing for them to ask questions and to be honest. I guess what, you know, as your sons
are getting older and you're probably looking to, okay, they're not going to be, I mean, I'm very
much in the throes of very small children. My oldest is five. And so I'm not looking to
the future and like, it's hard for me to picture them being on their own without me, but I'm sure
as they get kind of in that teenager area and Chris is, you know, dealing with this as well as
his children, you know, are growing up as well. What are your hopes for your kids and what are
your practical things that you're doing for them to hopefully equip them to be, you know, followers
of God in this culture that we're living in right now?
Josh Colson, I mean, I don't have a roadmap for being a good dad. I can tell you what my own
parents did. My brothers and I are all three of us are in Christian ministry or at least one's a
theology professor and one's a pastor and then I'm whatever the heck I am.
Wait, so you have, there's three boys in your family and then you had three boys?
Yes. That's fun. I think they call that a curse.
I love my, sorry, I mean, not fun, a curse.
It's wonderful, but this is a very present tense conversation because I got a 12 year old and he's,
you know, his school is not, I wouldn't call it necessarily Christo-centric.
But my parents did a couple different things that I thought was good. They never hedged on their own
faith. They never tried to act like they believed something they didn't. They were always
transparent about, you know, my dad was a minister and they, we were surrounded by people who loved
Jesus and for whom Jesus meant everything our whole lives and they didn't seem like charlatans
to me in any respect. And yet my parents, they put us in secular schools, shall we say,
and they did it partly because they knew that if God became tied up with our authority structure
in adolescence, that they risked losing us to the faith. You know, again, losing, yeah.
And so they put us in schools that seemed almost antithetical to what they were trying to do at
home. And yet we went to church every single week. That was non-negotiable. That was just part of what
we respect. Our father, we go to church in the mornings. It wasn't like you do this because you
have to love God. It's because this is what we do. And there was no questioning that. And what we
saw at church was not a community of, you know, terrible hypocrites. What we saw was a bunch of
people who loved one another and were doing their best to sort of serve their neighbors.
And so church, I mean, there was times when it was extremely boring, you know, and we didn't want to
go and we wanted to sleep in and we were teenagers, but we had to go if we were home. And then they
listened to us as we spouted the most stupid, ill-considered, teenager nonsense imaginable in
terms of what we believed about the world. And they weren't threatened by it. They kind of,
they weren't, they didn't, they, you know, if we said something really dumb, they'd say, well,
I don't know if that's true. But they allowed us to have some, you know, some leash, I guess you
could say. Okay. And what happened was that when personal suffering occurred, all of us came
crawling back to God as the antidote or the answer to our issues. And it meant that they had to, as
parents, they had to suffer, you know, they had to suffer letting us have our rebellion a bit. I mean,
their prayer was always that we would have our nervous breakdowns early and without too much
collateral damage. And, you know, they, I don't know how they did it, but for, they were authentic
about their faith, transparent about it. We exposed to communities of faith that were vibrant. And then
they, in person, they allowed us the space to rebel in ways without, you know, hurting people.
Right. And we watched as we all came back. So in terms of my own children, I want to answer their
questions and get make, they go to church every single week. I think in terms of the secular
ideologies that I was exposed to, they had a sense, I think, that you could let those dogs hunt
a little bit, and they would disappoint you. If you, as parents, they came against them too strongly,
they would, they would provoke rebellion. And they would make something more desirable than it was.
But if you allow those dogs to hunt, and I'm talking about the sort of overarching
isms that we are exposed to, that they come off as hollow, you know, your exercise class
isn't going to bring you a casserole when your parents die. It's just not going to happen.
But also in that sense, like your politics aren't going to save you when your boyfriend
breaks up with you, you know, it's right. That's the fruit free. And when you royally
screw up and you get arrested, or you get a DUI, you're the, you know, whatever the ideological
enclave that you're, is not going to forgive you, they're going to distance themselves from you.
So they allowed us to experience that for ourselves. I don't know if that's for every
parent to do, but it worked in their case. And I'm trying to do something somewhat similar.
But because you know, I want to be like, I want to be like the good dad, I want to be the one that
they come to when they crash the car, not the one that they run from. And so that's my only prayer,
I want to be the one who can show them grace in the moments, you know, I want to enforce the law.
When it comes to you know, don't stick your finger in that light socket. Right, right.
Don't, you know, don't drink like, you know, before you're allowed to, please, you know,
that's against the law, period. But I want to be the person that they feel they can come to.
And so that involves a certain demonstration of my own, its fallibility.
That's huge. And I'm telling you that pattern so far, the conversations we've been hearing from
people is when, when young people seem to have the room to ask questions, the room to doubt,
the room to struggle. That's that's a not, you know, like you said, not the room to stick their

Let's try to figure out how much you can understand about why not to do that. And let's talk about

And, and I feel like we've we're seeing that pattern is that the ability to, to know I can

could be a really tough question. It could even be an offensive question
from a political perspective, perspective, or even a religious perspective. Like,
I think that's, that's really cool. It puts the parent in a tough position, though, you have to
absorb. That's right. You have to bite your tongue a lot. And you have to absorb some nonsense.
And pick your pick your moments, you know, right. That's, that's always my prayer as a parent,
like, Lord, please show me when I really, you know, when do I need to pick when do I need to

really need you, they won't come to you. That's right. Yeah. And like you were saying, I think you
said your parents were, I can't remember the exact word you use, but they were secure. They just,
they were confident and they weren't afraid of y'all asking those questions. And I think
even becoming a new parent recently and thinking through, you know, as we're like praying for his
future, I think that that is so new to me and, and evident in a new way of like, yes, I want my child
to love the Lord and I want him to, these are all my hopes for his future. And so when it comes to
thinking about the questions that he's going to have, that already creates fear in me. And so I,
that makes a lot of sense of how our first response would be. I mean, there's other responses,
obviously of like pride or whatever of like, you're challenging me, but even a fear of what does this
mean? What, and wanting to lash out from that standpoint. And I think your point of them resting
secure and just, you know, trusting your life with the Lord and being able to handle those questions,
I think is encouraging because I already feel that in myself of, of a fear of what,
what is he going to ask? What is he going to try? You know, and there's, there's hopefully,
from what I've heard, there's grace for parents too, who messes up. I'm banking on it.
By banking, you mean you're setting up a therapy account now for the therapy they're going to need
later. Yeah. Yes. That too. No, you're exactly right. That's because we do mess it up. Yeah.
I trust Chris on all this stuff. In fact, I've heard of parenting and devices and there's so
many, it's such a wild West out there, but it does give you appreciation for God. You think,
think of the crazy things that the Lord has, you know, had to hear. We were so certain. I mean,
because that's part of like growing up into adulthood as a journey into kind of uncertainty
or like, all I know is that, that I'm putting my faith in Jesus and that's just about it.
And when I think of how certain I was about everything, when I was 25, I kind of cringe,
I think, but God somehow loved me through it. And my parents did too. And that's a,
that's a picture of God's grace to deal with those who are really stumbling along. And, and
that makes me more excited to be a Christian rather than less.
Yeah. Okay. So our kind of traditional final question is if you, if someone's listening now,
who is in the process of, of really struggling, of, of deconstructing,
what would you tell them? What's your advice?
Um, I would say, um,
go to try to find a good therapist to, um, I think ask the questions. Hopefully you can find
someone that you can really talk to, but, um, figure if you can, if you have identified the
emotional wounds that, um, and, and those are going to, they may take a lifetime to heal from.
And if you need to walk away from the church for a season, do it. Um, I think that's important,
but I just don't try not to kid you to be honest about where this is an intellectual thing versus
an emotional thing and where the emotional healing needs to take place. Um, I would seek help
because those, those, those wounds, if you get consumed with resentment about your past,
it will eat you alive. And, um, there are, um, ways there are people have dealt with, um,
um, uh, these, these, these, there's help. Um, and I, I hope and pray that yes, that God in his,
God's timing will, um, you know, become a, be revealed to, to, to be, you know,
actually the loving God that I, I've experienced, but I would say that don't, don't, don't, uh,
do it in a half speed, like go there, but look for the wounds and, um, deal with the heart issues.
And you may find that, um, the head stuff will, um, however it resolves, it will be, um, uh,
give a, it will be more wholesome, I guess in the wholehearted, uh, way.
Hmm.
Yeah. That's, that's what I'd say. I think, I think a lot of times that, uh, Jesus remains
as compelling as ever. Um, it's, it's more once we have to cough up the hairball of the pain
that we've, uh, we've had. And to really admit that it's been just that painful and that, um,
but yeah, I would think the degree of honesty about where's the emotional pain, um, and, and,
and to kind of actually deal with that rather than allow it to completely drive the train
of your intellectual and spiritual life for the next 30 years, um, would be sad.
Yeah. That's a really good point. And it is, it is, that is a great reminder. There are places you
can go. There are churches that do get this that can be safe. There are relationships and friendships
and you just, these, you got to find the, those people who can have that conversation with you and,
and work through the, the trauma, the pain, the, the, the harm. And that can be in a counseling
setting. It can be in, in a, those are, those are some great options. So yeah, we would, we would say
the same thing. Just don't the, the, the, the answer of just stopping at the deconstruction level.
Um, we've just not found that to be necessary and we can keep, we can keep working.
Cough up the hairball. David's all that's, uh, up there. Well, that's right. We'll be coming back
to that one. I'm sure many times. Yeah. Well, David, thank you so much. Yeah. For your thoughtful
responses, man. Seriously. It's been so good. I'm excited to go read your book. I haven't had
a chance to read it yet. I'm, my husband's read it and I'm so excited now. Oh, well, thanks,
Bryn. Thank you, Colson. Thank you, Chris, for having me. I hope it's, I don't know. I mean,
I honestly am an actual low anthropologist. I hope, I hope what I've said has been helpful.
It's been amazing. It's been really great. It's been a lot of words. It's been a lot of words.
Well, we really appreciate it. The people who are listening that we've found or the people that are
sending their friends to this or their kids to this, this, this podcast, um, that's what the,
sometimes the, the stories, the individual stories that as what we've wrestled through and
others have wrestled through have been really compelling to them. And, and why that if you have
a realistic perspective, why haven't you walked away? Well, that's, we, they need, they need to
hear that. They need to hear some examples of, I'm not, I'm not pretending like there's no, you know,
this is a, not a pay no attention to the man behind the curtain kind of faith. Um, and so if I'm,
if I'm honest about the stuff that's going on behind the curtain, how can I stick with it?
And what's the real story here? So I appreciate that David very much. And I, I do recommend your
materials, your, the conferences you do, the, the teaching you do. I have been, I love that
it makes me think differently than my intuition is time after time. Um, and I find my spirit,
encouraged by that. So David, thank you. Thank you for joining us for this episode of
Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South
Spring Baptist church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
